questions.question: A 23-year-old man came to the OPD with complaints of vomiting for which he was prescribedmetoclopramide. What is the primary mechanism of action of this drug?

options.B: Sensitization of muscarinic receptors on smooth muscles

questions.question: Which of the following actions is exhibited by metoclopramide?

options.A: Inhibits cholinergic smooth muscle stimulation in the gastrointestinal tract
options.B: Decreases the lower esophageal sphincter pressure

questions.explanation: Metoclopramide enhances gastrointestinal motility.Acetylcholine increases gastrointestinal motility and lower esophageal sphincter (LES) tone.Dopamine which is an inhibitory neurotransmitter suppresses ACh release. This decreasesgastrointestinal motility and LES tone. Therefore, D2 receptor inhibition augments ACh releaseand enhances GI motility and LES tone.The action of metoclopramide is generally confined to the upper digestive tract and an increase incolonic motility is clinically insignificant.

questions.question: A patient presented to the casualty with signs of dehydration due to severe vomiting. Theintern gave the patient a parenteral medication, following which the patient developedgrimacing and abnormal posturing. What could have been the inciting drug for this reaction?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario describes the adverse effects characteristic of metoclopramide. Themost common adverse effects of metoclopramide involve the central nervous system because itcrosses the blood-brain barrier (BBB) and blocks the central D2 receptors.The adverse effects include:• Restlessness••••• Drowsiness• InsomniaAnxietyAgitation• Extrapyramidal effects - acute reaction with high doses and long-term therapy. (due to centraldopamine receptor blockade)• Dystonias• Akathisia•Parkinsonian features• Tardive dyskinesiaAdverse events are more common among the elderly. Long-term use should be avoided unlessabsolutely necessary.829

questions.question: 820A patient developed abnormal posturing and grimacing following the administration ofmetoclopramide. Which drug will you administer to manage this patient?
questions.explanation: The given scenario is suggestive of dystonia associated with D2 blocker (metoclopramide) use.Promethazine is the drug of choice.It is a first-generation antihistaminic having significant central anticholinergic activity.

questions.question: Which of the following drugs is implicated in prolonging QT interval and causing seriousarrhythmias?
questions.explanation: Cisapride is associated with prolongation of QT interval and causation of serious ventriculararrhythmias.Prolongation of QT interval is due to blockade of rapid delayed rectifier potassium channels. It isbanned or has restricted use in most of the countries.Ondansetron is associated with asymptomatic electrocardiogram changes, including prolongationof PT and QTc intervals.

questions.question: Which of the following drugs do not act as a prokinetic agent by 5HT4 agonism?
questions.explanation: Domperidone does not have any 5HT4 agonist action. It mainly acts by D2 antagonist action.5HT4 agonism and D2 antagonism can result in prokinetic action by increasing the cholinergicactivity of the gut.The 5HT4 agonist action is shown by:••MetoclopramideCisapride• Mosapride• Itopride• Renzapride

questions.question: Which of the following is not a prokinetic?
questions.explanation: Diphenylmethane is not a prokinetic agent. Its derivative (Bisacodyl) is used as a laxative.Prokinetic agents are the drugs that increase GI motility and transit of material in the GI tract.These agents include:••Dopamine receptor antagonists- metoclopramide and domperidone⚫ Serotonin receptor agonists- cisapride and prucalopride• Motilin•Macrolide antibiotics mimicking motilin - erythromycin830• Miscellaneous agents:• Sincalide (C-terminal octapeptide of CCK)•Camicinal (motilin receptor agonist)• Relamorelin (ghrelin receptor agonist)• Velusetrag and naronapride (5HT4 agonists)

questions.question: 821A 45-year-old male with unhealthy eating practices now complains of constipation. He tookbisacodyl, following which he had symptomatic relief. Which group of drugs does this belongto?
questions.explanation: Bisacodyl is a stimulant laxative.Stimulant laxatives act by irritation of the intestinal mucosa and direct action on myenteric plexusneurons stimulating motility and secretion.Examples of stimulant/irritant laxatives are:•Bisacodyl• Sodium picosulfate•Anthraquinones like senna, cascara sagrada• Castor oil

questions.question: A colonoscopy of an elderly patient revealed brownish pigmented lesions as shown below. Headmitted to chronic laxative abuse. Which of the following laxatives is most likely to causethis condition?
questions.explanation: The above colonoscopy image depicts a brownish moiré pattern that is indicative of melanosiscoli. Chronic use of anthraquinone laxatives like senna and cascara sagrada can cause melanosiscoli.Bisacodyl is also implicated in causing melanosis coli.

questions.question: You want to prescribe a bulk-forming laxative to an elderly patient with constipation. Whichamong the following would you not prescribe?822
questions.explanation: Liquid paraffin is not a bulk-forming laxative. It is a mineral oil and acts as a stool softener.It is rarely used in clinical practice today because of its drawbacks, such as:• Bland and unpleasant taste• Risk of lipoid pneumonia••Anal leakageBulk-forming laxatives are:•• Bran•Psyllium• Methylcellulose831• Polycarbophil

questions.question: A 3-year-old child is brought to the pediatric OPD by his mother with complaints of acutewatery diarrhea for 2 days. Oral rehydration solution, zinc supplement, and a peripheralenkephalinase inhibitor were prescribed. Which of the following drugs did he prescribe?
questions.explanation: Racecadotril is a peripheral enkephalinase inhibitor.Enkephalins are endogenous delta-opioid receptor agonists that decrease intestinal secretionswithout affecting motility. Enkephalinase is the enzyme that degrades enkephalin.Racecadotril, by inhibiting the enkephalinase enzyme increases enkephalin level and acts as anantisecretory agent in diarrhea. It has minimal/no effect on motility. Racecadotril is indicated forsymptomatic treatment of diarrhea in infants and children.Options B and C: Diphenoxylate and loperamide are µ-opioid receptor agonists.Option D: Linaclotide is a guanylate cyclase agonist.

questions.question: A 30-year-old male who is on anti-retroviral therapy presents with complaints of diarrhea forthree days. An infectious etiology is ruled out on work-up. Which of the following drugs ispreferred to manage his diarrhea?
questions.explanation: This is a case of non-infectious diarrhea associated with antiretroviral therapy (ART). Crofelemeris indicated for non-infectious diarrhea associated with ART in HIV/AIDS.Crofelemer has minimal systemic absorption. It acts by inhibiting the cyclic AMP-stimulatedCFTR chloride channel and calcium-activated chloride channels on the luminal side of theintestine.

questions.question: A 38-year-old woman complains of recurrent episodes of constipation and crampy abdominalpain for the last 4 months. The pain is relieved on defecation. After investigations, a diagnosisof irritable bowel syndrome with constipation is considered. Which of the following drugswould you prescribe?
questions.explanation: The drug used in irritable bowel syndrome with constipation is lubiprostone.It is approved for chronic idiopathic constipation and constipation-predominant irritable bowelsyndrome (in female patients >18 years). It acts by stimulating Cl-channels in the intestine andincreasing fluid secretion in the gut. This decreases the transit time.Eluxadoline is an FDA-approved opioid drug for the treatment of diarrhea-predominant IBS inadults.

questions.question: The use of which of the following drugs is associated with ischemic colitis?
questions.explanation: Ischemic colitis is associated with the use of alosetron. It is a 5HT3 antagonist that may suppressintestinal relaxation leading to ischemic colitis in susceptible individuals.It is approved for resistant diarrhea-predominant irritable bowel syndrome in female patients.It is either withdrawn/ has restricted use because of the serious side effect.832

questions.question: A patient who is suffering from chronic constipation is prescribed a guanylcycline C agonist.Identify the drug.
questions.explanation: The guanylcycline-C (GC-C) agonist indicated in chronic constipation is linaclotide.Linaclotide is a peptide agonist that activates GC-C which leads to increased synthesis ofcyclic-GMP. This results in enhanced chloride and bicarbonate secretion into the intestinal lumenleading to increased water secretion and enhanced motility.It is indicated in constipation-predominant IBS in females and in chronic idiopathic constipationin adults.

questions.question: Prucalopride is a
questions.explanation: Prucalopride is a specific 5HT4 receptor agonist which increases bowel movements.It is approved for use in women with chronic constipation where other laxatives have failed toprovide relief.

questions.question: A 40-year-old woman suffering from erratic bowel habits for the past few months isdiagnosed with diarrhea-predominant irritable bowel syndrome. Which antibiotic isspecifically approved for the treatment of her condition?
questions.explanation: The antibiotic that is specifically approved for diarrhea-predominant IBS is rifaximin. It is anRNA synthesis inhibitor. It may provide benefit by altering the gastrointestinal flora favorably.Rifabutin, rifampicin and rifapentine are antitubercular agents.

questions.question: A 20-year-old primiparous woman came to the OPD with complaints of nausea and vomitingat 8 weeks of gestation. Which of the following is specifically indicated to providesymptomatic relief in this patient?
questions.explanation: Doxylamine is indicated with pyridoxine to reduce mild to moderate nausea and vomiting in theearly stages of pregnancy.It is a histamine H1 antagonist and its efficacy is improved when combined with pyridoxine.Combinations of domperidone, dolasetron and metoclopramide with pyridoxine are notspecifically indicated in pregnancy.

questions.question: What is the drug of choice in a patient complaining of nausea and vomiting, 2 days aftercommencement of a cisplatin-based chemotherapeutic regimen?
questions.explanation: This patient is most likely suffering from delayed emesis associated with cancer chemotherapy.Combined therapy with aprepitant (NK-1/ neurokinin-1 receptor antagonist), a 5-HT3-receptorantagonist, and dexamethasone is the best treatment in delayed emesis associated with cancerchemotherapy.833Delayed chemotherapy-induced vomiting is any emesis occurring >24 hours afterchemotherapy. If NK-1 receptor antagonists are not used in the combination, delayed emesis isprevented only in 30% of the patients. Usage of 5HT3 antagonists alone has no role in thetreatment of delayed emesis.

questions.question: An AIDS patient presents with anorexia and weight loss. Which of the following is a naturallyextracted cannabinoid that is approved for his condition?
questions.explanation: Dronabinol or delta-9-tetrahydrocannabinol is a cannabinoid that can be extracted naturally.It is the only cannabinoid that is approved for anorexia and weight loss associated with AIDS. It isobtained from the marijuana plant or can be synthesized chemically.Option B: Nabilone is a synthetic cannabinoid.Dronabinol and nabilone are approved for the treatment of refractory cases ofchemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting.Option C: Tibolone is a 19-norsteroid derivative specifically to be used for hormone replacementtherapy.Option D: Cannabidiol is a cannabinoid approved for the treatment of seizures associatedwith Lennox-Gastaut syndrome, Dravet syndrome, or tuberous sclerosis complex.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about aprepitant is false?

options.C: Ameliorate nausea and vomiting induced by chemotherapy

questions.explanation: Aprepitant is a high-affinity NK1 receptor antagonist that blocks the emetic action of substance P.Aprepitant is well absorbed orally and crosses the blood-brain barrier.Co-administration of oral aprepitant with dexamethasone and ondansetron significantly enhancesthe antiemetic efficacy against the highly emetogenic side effects of chemotherapeutic drugs likecisplatin and cyclophosphamide.It is metabolized in the liver by the CYP450 enzyme.

questions.question: Which of the following antiemetic drugs also decreases acid secretion due to its action on H1receptors?
questions.explanation: An antiemetic drug that also decreases acid secretion due to its action on H1 histamine receptorsis promethazine.The central anticholinergic activity of promethazine is responsible for antiemetic action.

questions.question: The 5HT3 antagonist having maximum potency in chemotherapy-induced vomiting is:
questions.explanation: The 5HT3 antagonist having maximum potency in chemotherapy-induced vomiting ispalonosetron.834It has a high affinity for 5HT3 and is also the longest-acting 5HT3 antagonist. This makes it moreeffective in delayed emesis associated with chemotherapy.During chemotherapy, there is cell lysis and 5HT (serotonin) is released from the gut mucosa. Thereleased serotonin acts on the 5HT3 receptors, activating the vagal afferents in the gut that carrythe emetogenic impulses to the nucleus tractus solitarius and chemoreceptor trigger zone. Theselective blockade of 5HT3 receptors reduces the emetogenic impulses.Granisetron, dolasetron, and ondansetron are also effective for chemotherapy-induced vomiting.Cilansetron is a new 5HT3 antagonist indicated for irritable bowel syndrome with diarrhea.

questions.question: Most effective antiemetic for chemotherapy-induced vomiting is
questions.explanation: Among the given options, the most effective antiemetic for chemotherapy-induced vomiting isgranisetron.Granisetron is a 5HT3 receptor antagonist. They are the most effective drugs for the treatment ofchemotherapy-induced and post-operative nausea and vomiting.Palonosetron is a second-generation 5HT3 antagonist that has the highest affinity for 5HT3receptors and has the maximum potency. It is also the longest acting that makes it effective indelayed emesis associated with chemotherapy. Palonosetron has minimal/no propensity to causeQT interval prolongation.

questions.question: QT interval prolongation is minimal with which of the following 5-HT3 antagonists?
questions.explanation: Palonosetron is a second-generation 5-HT3 antagonist and has minimal/no propensity to causeQT prolongation.First-generation 5-HT3 antagonists have an increased risk of QT interval prolongation.Intravenous dolasetron is contraindicated for prophylaxis of chemotherapy-induced nausea andvomiting for the same reason.

questions.question: Which of the following NK1 receptor antagonists has the longest half-life?
questions.explanation: Rolapitant has the longest plasma half-life of 180 hours. It is a highly selective NK1 receptorantagonist.

questions.question: A young male developed 5 episodes of loose stools 2 hours after eating in a restaurant. He isafebrile and has mild dehydration. What should be the treatment?Ciprofloxacin and tinidazoleb) Only ciprofloxacinc) Only ORSd) Ciprofloxacin, tinidazole and ORSQuestion 28:You and your friend plan for a mountain trip for the day after. What medication would youadvise him to help with his motion sickness?

options.A: Ranitidine tablet before start of trip
options.C: Scopolamine patch the night before trip
options.D: Omeprazole the night before and before start of trip

questions.explanation: It is a case of acute diarrhea in an afebrile, stable patient which can be managed with ORS alone.Management of diarrhea:835• Mild-moderate dehydration - ORS.• Severe dehydration- IV fluids are given.•Afebrile patient - No antibiotics are given.• Febrile patient - empirical antibiotics. If only bacterial etiology is suspected, ciprofloxacin isgiven. If giardiasis is suspected, metronidazole or tinidazole are recommended.
